title: END OF LESSON REVIEW (Unit 4: Multiple choice in listening)
content: Review exercise for IELTS Listening Section 4 - Questions 31-40

questions.instructions:
Questions 31-35

Choose the correct letter A – C
questions.question: 31. Interview situations
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is A. stimulate mixed feelings amongst candidates. Barry mentions that getting to an interview can feel both rewarding and daunting. In the IELTS Listening test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The speaker mentions that getting to the interview stage can feel both rewarding and daunting, showing mixed feelings.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Not quite. Listen carefully at the beginning when the speaker discusses how candidates feel about interviews - they mention it can feel both rewarding and daunting.

mc_options.feedback: Correct! The speaker mentions that getting to the interview stage can feel both rewarding and daunting, which are mixed feelings.

mc_options.text: require us to demonstrate similar skills to the real world
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The speaker actually says that interview scenarios are quite unrealistic, as in usual life it's not appropriate to talk at length about personal achievements.

mc_options.text: usually last for an hour or more
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The speaker mentions that you will have up to an hour, most often a shorter period of time, to impress.

stimulate mixed feelings amongst candidates

Correct! The speaker clearly states that the way you present yourself through speech is of even greater significance than appearance, and quotes Simon Holworth saying verbal communication skills are one of the main reasons candidates are offered or rejected for a job.

questions.question: 35. It is not possible to confirm the number of words in the English language
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is C. as individual parts of language are often classified differently. The speaker explains that numbers vary depending on how a word is actually defined, giving the example of 'book' being classified as one word or separately for different usages. In the IELTS Listening test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The speaker explains that numbers vary depending on how a word is actually defined, with some classification systems counting different usages as one word and others classifying them separately.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Not quite. Listen carefully when the speaker discusses why word counts vary - they explain that it depends on how a word is defined and give the example of 'book' being classified differently under different systems.

mc_options.text: as it is difficult to judge what is 'English' or really Latin, French or German
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the speaker mentions English has been influenced by French and Latin, this is not given as the reason why word counts vary. The reason is that classification systems define words differently.

mc_options.text: as technical and new words are added all the time
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the speaker mentions English continues to be influenced by other languages, this is not the reason given for why word counts vary. The reason is that different classification systems count words differently.

mc_options.text: as individual parts of language are often classified differently
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The speaker explains that estimates vary depending on how a word is actually defined, giving the example of 'book' - under some classification systems it counts as one word, while in others it is classified separately for each different usage and meaning.

questions.options:
as it is difficult to judge what is 'English' or really Latin, French or German
as technical and new words are added all the time
as individual parts of language are often classified differently

questions.instructions:
Questions 36 and 37

Choose TWO letters A-E

Which TWO apply to active vocabulary?
questions.question: 36-37. Which TWO apply to active vocabulary?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answers are D (University graduates have around 60,000) and E (Are not only understood but regularly used). The speaker explains that active vocabulary relates to words we actually use in speech and writing, and that an average university graduate may demonstrate an active vocabulary of 60,000 words. In the IELTS Listening test, you should always attempt every question - there's no penalty for wrong answers.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Active vocabulary refers to words that we actually use in speech and writing (not just understand), and research suggests an average university graduate may demonstrate an active vocabulary of 60,000 words.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Not quite. Listen carefully when the speaker defines active and passive vocabulary - active vocabulary relates to words we actually use in speech and writing, and a university graduate may demonstrate an active vocabulary of 60,000 words.

mc_options.text: Relates to words with several meanings
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. This is not mentioned in relation to active vocabulary. Active vocabulary refers to words we actually use in speech and writing.

mc_options.text: Not necessarily spoken but often written
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The speaker states that active vocabulary relates to words that we actually use in speech AND writing, not just written.

mc_options.text: Add up to around 15,000 words for the average person
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. 15,000 words is mentioned as the passive vocabulary (words we understand but don't necessarily use), not the active vocabulary.
Correct! The speaker states that research suggested an average university graduate may demonstrate an active vocabulary of 60,000 words.

mc_options.text: Are not only understood but regularly used
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The speaker clearly defines active vocabulary as words that we actually use in speech and writing, as opposed to passive vocabulary which are words we understand but do not necessarily use.

questions.options:
Relates to words with several meanings
Not necessarily spoken but often written
Add up to around 15,000 words for the average person
University graduates have around 60,000
Are not only understood but regularly used

sections.transcript:
We're here today to talk about possible ways of impressing an interviewer or panel when searching for that highly desirable career opportunity.

Getting to the interview stage after what could have been months of persistent application sending, can feel both Q31rewarding and daunting. Interview scenarios are, if you think about it, quite unrealistic as in our usual lives it is not appropriate to talk at length about our own personal achievements, strengths and capabilities. However, during an interview, you will have up to an hour, most often a shorter period of time, to impress.

Appearance counts for a lot, especially on first impression, so it is important to dress appropriately and professionally for the interview. Another important consideration, of even greater significance, is Q32the way in which you present yourself through speech. Obviously the company considered you potentially worthy of working for them, based on the details in your application, since they have invited you for interview in the first place. However, all positive impressions could be dispelled if you fail to present yourself eloquently. Simon Holworth of Recruitment International says that he believes a candidate's verbal communication skills are one the main reasons they may be offered a position or rejected for a job.

Recruitment experts hold that the vocabulary and grammar with which we express ourselves will be used by the listener – either consciously or subconsciously – as they form an impression of our intelligence and academic abilities. Potential employers will often be seeking staff who they believe Q33are able to best assimilate with the existing team and culture of the organisation and a similar academic outlook will often have a bearing on this.

While attempting to use vocabulary that is far outside your normal communication patterns would almost certainly backfire as any related discomfort would be picked up by the listener, Q34experts advise that thinking ahead about what types of questions you may be asked when attending interview for a specific role and pre-planning vocabulary that could impress beforehand may well help to secure you the position you are looking for. It is important to be sure that you understand the meanings of such words that may crop up in the interview and also be able to demonstrate that you can use them correctly.

It is probable that English incorporates one of the largest vocabularies when compared to other languages; this is mainly due to its historical background and the various influences which have occurred over time. Originally a Germanic language, it has also been influenced by French and Latin hence the larger number of different words it contains than what could be considered the purer Germanic and Romance languages, and as a modern day international language, English continues to be influenced by others.

The numbers of words included in the language are difficult to measure and various estimates place this anywhere between ¼ and ¾ of a million words – depending on how a word is actually defined. For example the word 'book' is a noun describing printed material or a verb describing reservation of a table in a restaurant. Q35Under some classification systems this may count as one word, while in others it is classified separately for each of its different usages and meanings.

As individuals, it can be said that we have both an active and a passive vocabulary – Q36Q37the former related to words that we actually use in speech and writing and the latter referring to words we understand the meaning of, but do not necessarily use ourselves. Different people's expanse of vocabulary varies and one research study suggested that an average university graduate may demonstrate an active vocabulary of 60,000 words and a passive understanding of a further 15,000.

Trying to impress by using words which are outside of the passive understanding of the average educated person at interview is unlikely to create a particularly positive impression; however, most of us could benefit from exercises in extension of the words we use and being able to present ourselves fluently and coherently is vitally important. Learning new vocabulary as an adult can be fun. One of the best ways of doing so it to read more, try guessing the meaning of unknown words from the context of the passage, make a list of words you are unsure of then check their meanings in a dictionary. Playing board games based around word or vocabulary puzzles are both also fun and productive ways of Q38enhancing your communication capabilities.

A candidate's inability to answer question without constant interference from verbal crutches such as 'like', 'you know', 'thingy', can be very off-putting to potential employers, as can Q39grammatical errors. Some questions asked at interview can be tricky and warrant some thinking time, but the best way of dealing with such situations is not to try to bluster through, but to confidently announce the need for some thinking time. Phrases such as 'that's a very interesting question, please give me a minute to consider it.' show that the person is, with control, deliberating an Q40intelligent response.

While it is impossible to pre-empt every question that you may be asked in an interview, planning and considering possibilities, as with most aspects of life, can certainly not detract from your chance of success.
